ExampleGroup.ExampleInfo: The Telerik DataForm allows editing any object at run-time.\nDevelopers can specify pre-defined editors for each field of their object and also create custom editors with ease. The data form can commit the changes made to the object immediately, on lost focus or when the user explicitly chooses to commit them. The Telerik DataForm also supports validation, custom layouts and more.
ExampleGroup.ShortDescription: A powerful data form control with a rich feature set.

Example.ExampleInfo: This example demonstrates a simple scenario using the Telerik DataForm.
Example.ShortDescription: Getting started with the Telerik DataForm.

ExampleGroup.ExampleInfo:
The Telerik ListView supports all the major functionality inherent for list control:
 - handling large sets of data through UI virtualization,
 - pull to refresh gesture to refresh the data source,
 - load on demand to update the data source with new items,
 - item selection,
 - filtering, grouping, sorting of the view model,
 - various layout strategies such as horizontal, vertical, wrapped and staggered lists,
 - swipe-to-execute,
 - item reordering,
 - animations etc.

Some of the ListView examples use the Flickr API but are not endorsed or certified by Flickr.
ExampleGroup.ShortDescription: A powerful data list control with extended feature set.

Example.ExampleInfo:
This example demonstrates the Slide Layout manager for Telerik ListView.

This layout allows user to easily slide from one item to another in a way suitable for image galleries.

The example contains a list with destinations which you can browse by swiping left or right and view more info on tap.
Example.ShortDescription: Slide layout in the Telerik ListView.

Example.ExampleInfo:
This example demonstrates the Deck of Cards layout manager for Telerik ListView.

This layout stacks items in a way which resembles a deck of cards, where one item is fully visible and others are shown in a perspective.

The example contains a list with recipes which you can like or dislike by swiping respectively to the right or to the left. You can also scroll forward or backward by swiping up and down.
Example.ShortDescription: Deck of Cards layout in the Telerik ListView.

Example.ExampleInfo:
You can use the built-in Android layout managers to specify how the Telerik ListView positions its items.

You can use the LinearLayoutManager to show items in a vertical or horizontal scrolling list, the GridLayoutManager to show items in a grid and the StaggeredGridLayoutManager to display items in a staggered grid. For more advanced layout scenarios you can create a custom layout manager by extending the RecyclerView.LayoutManager class.

To switch between the different layout modes use the buttons located in the top-right corner of the page.

This example uses the Flickr API but is not endorsed or certified by Flickr.
Example.ShortDescription: Supported layout modes in the Telerik ListView.

Example.ExampleInfo: Reordering items through a drag and drop gesture can be enabled by adding an ItemReorderBehavior to the list of behaviors.
Example.ShortDescription: Reordering of items in the Telerik ListView.

Example.ExampleInfo: The ListView supports horizontal and vertical scrolling in all of its layout modes.\n\nThis example uses the Flickr API but is not endorsed or certified by Flickr.
Example.ShortDescription: Horizontal and vertical scrolling in the Telerik ListView.

Example.ExampleInfo: The Telerik ListView provides support for both single and multiple selection. Selection can be enabled by adding a SelectionBehavior to the list of behaviors.
Example.ShortDescription: Selection in the Telerik ListView.

ExampleGroup.ExampleInfo:
The Telerik CalendarView for Android can be used for presenting events information, date picking and other general calendar usages.

It provides three different modes for date presentation:
- Year,
- Month,
- Week.

The different modes can be easily switched through intuitive gestures. There are also three selection modes:
- Single,
- Multiple,
- Range.

The dates that are presented can be easily restricted with providing Min and Max dates.

The examples for the control include:
- A first look example which demonstrates how events can be integrated
- A range selection example which demonstrates how this widget can be used for date picking.
ExampleGroup.ShortDescription: Calendar component with Year, Month and Week views.

Example.ExampleInfo:
First look at Telerik Calendar for Android.

The example demonstrates how the widget displays dates from one week, one month and one year depending on the current display mode.

The week view and the month view also show how events information can be integrated in the calendar cell's content.

By using intuitive gestures you can switch from Week to Month or from Month to Year and vice versa. The modes can also be changed through a Spinner.

The calendar follows your locale, so if you change the Language from your device's Settings, you will see that the names of the months and the days in the calendar will follow your change.
Example.ShortDescription: Year, Month and Week views inside the Telerik CalendarView.

Example.ExampleInfo:
Range selection inside the Telerik CalendarView.

It demonstrates how the widget can be used inside a popup for picking dates. The example represents an excerpt from a hotel reservation app where you can use the calendar widget to select the range of your stay and book a hotel of your choice.

The calendar is configured to use range selection where you tap on the first and the last date and the whole range between them gets selected. The Min date is set to today, so that you can't make a reservation for a previous date.
Example.ShortDescription: Range selection inside the Telerik CalendarView.

Example.ExampleInfo:
Inline events display mode example in Telerik CalendarView.

This example demonstrates how you can configure the calendar to display information about the events for a specific date in a list that animates in between the calendar cells.

In order to see the events for a date, tap on a date that is marked with a dot above its number. To close the events information tap anywhere outside the list with events.
Example.ShortDescription: Inline events in the Telerik CalendarView.

ExampleGroup.ExampleInfo:
The Telerik Chart for Android supports all the essential series for visualizing your application data.

- LineSeries,
- SplineSeries,
- FinancialSeries,
- AreaSeries,
- ScatterPointSeries,
- SplineAreaSeries,
- ScatterBubbleSeries,
- BarSeries,
- RangeBarSeries,
- PieSeries,
- DoughnutSeries,
- IndicatorSeries.

Built on top of a highly optimized rendering engine, the Telerik Chart provides smooth experience for all of its interaction capabilities such as Trackball, Tooltip, Pan & Zoom and Selection.

The Telerik Chart is also compliant with the latest Holo design principles.

GalleryExample.ExampleInfo:
A scatter chart is a two-dimensional graphical representation of a set of data where each x/y variable is represented on the graph as a dot. This type of chart can be used in to visually describe relationships between two numerical parameters or to represent distributions.

The difference between line and scatter charts is that line charts connect the data points to show every change, whereas the scatter is better suited to show a 'best fit' line. The data points are scattered about the line. The closer the data points are to the line the stronger the correlation or affect one variable has on the other.

The Bubble chart is a flavor of the scatter chart. In scatter charts, the x-axis displays one numeric field and the y-axis displays another, making it easy to see the relationship between the two values for all the items in the chart. In a bubble chart, a third numeric field controls the size of the data points.

Example.ShortDescription: Scatter point series.
Scatter bubble series.

GalleryExample.ExampleInfo: Line charts are often used to plot changes in data over time, such as monthly temperature changes or daily changes in stock market prices.\n\nLine graphs have a vertical and a horizontal axis. If you are plotting changes in data over time, time is plotted along the horizontal axis and your other data is plotted as individual points along the vertical axis.
GalleryExample.ShortDescription: Using Line and Spline series to monitor trends.

Example.ShortDescription: Line series.

GalleryExample.ExampleInfo:
Area charts are much like line charts, but they display different colors in the areas below the lines. This colorful and visual display distinguishes the data more clearly.

The Telerik Charting framework for Android supports STACK, STACK100 and standard plotting modes.

Stacked area charts display the trend of the contribution of each value over time or other category data.

100% stacked area charts display the trend of the percentage that each value contributes over time or other category data.
GalleryExample.ShortDescription: Show trends on the same diagram with STACK, STACK100 and standard plotting mode.

Example.ShortDescription: Area series.

GalleryExample.ExampleInfo:
Bar charts are one of the most common types of graph used to display data. Sometimes known as 'column charts', bar charts are most often used to show amounts or the number of times a value occurs.

Bar charts are useful for comparing multiple series of data (i.e. providing snapshots of data at particular points in time). With Bar and RangeBar series you can easily visualize data points as bar blocks where the height of each bar denotes the magnitude of its data point.

Styling has been made easy so you can quickly differentiate each bar.
GalleryExample.ShortDescription: Compare sets of data by visualizing the data points as vertical bars.

Example.ShortDescription: Clustered Bar series description here.

GalleryExample.ExampleInfo:
Pie charts are used to display the contribution of fractional parts to a whole.

For example, if a company has five divisions, and the pie chart shows profits per division, the sum of all the slices (divisions) is the sum of profits for the company.

Each data point is a pie slice with arc size proportional to the magnitude of the pointâ€™s value.

Pie and doughnut charts are most useful when you have to compare percentage values of different items that are part of the same series.
GalleryExample.ShortDescription: Each data point is a pie slice with arc size proportional to the magnitude of the pointâ€™s value.

GalleryExample.ExampleInfo:
An open-high-low-close chart (also known as OHLC chart) is a type of chart typically used to illustrate movements in the price of a financial instrument over time.

Open-High-Low-Close (OHLC) bar charts provide volatility information that line charts lack.

OHLC charts help you evaluate volatility by the height of the bars and the conviction of the buyers and sellers by the price range between the open and close marks.

The candlestick chart is another way of displaying market price data. Both charts show the exact same data, i.e. the opening, high, low, and closing prices during a particular time frame.
GalleryExample.ShortDescription: Financial series are used to visualize the ohlc values of collected financial data for stock prices.

Example.ShortDescription: Candle sticks represent ohlc financial data using candle-like shapes.
Example.ExampleInfo: Candle sticks are representing the open, high, low, close values of financial data using candle-like shapes, where empty candles represent periods where the close value is lesser than the open value.

Example.ShortDescription: Ohlc series represent ohlc data using stick figures.
Example.ExampleInfo: Ohlc series represent ohlc data, by using stick figures. Every figure consists of 3 parts. There is one vertical stick representing the high and low values and two horizontal sticks representing the open and close values.
The details in a large data set can easily be seen with the pan and zoom feature. Pinch in, out or pan to see the desired level of detail.
Example.ShortDescription: See the details in a data set by using pinch and pan gestures.

Example.ExampleInfo: You can feed various data types into the chart. Depending on the chart type, numerical data can be distributed on the X-axis over other numbers, categories or points in time. RadChart uses several types of axes to plot its data: Linear, Categorical, Logarithmic, DateTimeCategorical and DateTimeContinuous.
Example.ShortDescription: Plot any type of data using Linear, Numerical, Logarithmic, DateTime and Categorical axes.

Example.ExampleInfo: Annotations are visual elements that can be used to highlight certain areas on the chart and denote statistical significance. An annotation is an explanatory image, text or another visual element which can be anchored to a single point or a point range. The currently supported annotations are: Grid Line, Plot Band and Custom annotations.
Example.ShortDescription: Visual elements for highlighting certain areas and denoting statistical significance.
Indicators are used extensively to predict changes in stock trends or price patterns.
Example.ExampleInfo: Indicators are used extensively to predict changes in stock trends or price patterns by using specific algorithms and chart series to visualize them.
